sn41.7:4.1: At one time Venerable Godatta was staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.
sn41.7:4.2: Then Citta the householder went up to Venerable Godatta,
sn41.7:4.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn41.7:4.5: “Householder, the limitless heart’s release, and the heart’s release through nothingness, and the heart’s release through emptiness, and the signless heart’s release: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
sn41.7:4.6: “Sir, there is a way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
sn41.7:4.7: But there’s also a way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.
sn41.7:5.1: And what’s the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing?
sn41.7:5.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
sn41.7:5.3: In the same way they spread a heart full of love above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
sn41.7:5.4: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
sn41.7:5.5: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
sn41.7:5.6: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
sn41.7:5.7: In the same way they spread a heart full of equanimity above, below, across, everywhere, all around—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
sn41.7:5.8: This is called the limitless heart’s release.
sn41.7:6.1: And what is the heart’s release through nothingness?
sn41.7:6.2: It’s when a mendicant—going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness—aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
sn41.7:6.3: This is called the heart’s release through nothingness.
sn41.7:7.1: And what is the heart’s release through emptiness?
sn41.7:7.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
sn41.7:7.3: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’
sn41.7:7.4: This is called the heart’s release through emptiness.
sn41.7:8.1: And what is the signless heart’s release?
sn41.7:8.2: It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless samādhi of the heart.
sn41.7:8.3: This is called the signless heart’s release.
sn41.7:8.4: This is the way in which these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
sn41.7:9.1: And what’s the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?
sn41.7:9.2: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of limits.
sn41.7:9.3: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and exterminated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
sn41.7:9.4: The unshakable heart’s release is said to be the best kind of limitless heart’s release.
sn41.7:9.5: That unshakable heart’s release is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
sn41.7:9.6: Greed is something, hate is something, and delusion is something.
sn41.7:9.7: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and exterminated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
sn41.7:9.8: The unshakable heart’s release is said to be the best kind of heart’s release through nothingness.
sn41.7:9.9: That unshakable heart’s release is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
sn41.7:9.10: Greed, hate, and delusion are makers of signs.
sn41.7:9.11: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and exterminated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.
sn41.7:9.12: The unshakable heart’s release is said to be the best kind of signless heart’s release.
sn41.7:9.13: That unshakable heart’s release is empty of greed, hate, and delusion.
sn41.7:9.14: This is the way in which they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
sn41.7:9.15: “You’re fortunate, householder, so very fortunate, to survey the Buddha’s deep teachings with the eye of wisdom.”
